body:
If you’re gonna be following the trend of a typical south side ghetto hood rat that trashes their house and yard and not even attempt to get a decent job than why would you expect good things to come your way? No one is gonna give you what you want for free. Spending your money on stupid things isn’t helping you. Being a thug and keeping up with your criminal record isn’t gonna help you. Having a Facebook that depicts you as a ratchet person isn’t going to help you. Making bad friends and hanging in the wrong crowd does not help you. Getting in trouble in school will not help you. Saying fuck the police isn’t gonna build a relationship. Being a problem in a neighborhood isn’t going to help your reputation. Maybe if you tried being a better person, people will help you because doing nothing good isn’t helping you. If you took care of what you got you’d be better off. Also blacks in America are extremely privileged compared to other nations. Welfare, food stamps, government assistance on housing, child support. Black people are so privileged here they destroy their own  country, community stores and homes in riots and suffer no consequence while being backed by political parties and the news media

Source: I am a black and Latin mixed boy that lives with his black family, that lives in a decent black neighborhood that fell victim into the hands section 8 people, I grew up in a mostly black school and town. I didn’t grow up with much either but I didn’t become an ass. I don’t care about your google search “sources” for something I personally seen and known.

There's no way you can be getting [this much](http://archive.is/NAh0Z) more in benefits while being oppressed. Everything about the system is designed to make blacks succeed; they can't just keep pointing the finger forever. They will though because it is in the best interests of a certain political party to keep them thinking the system is against them so they can control their votes.

author.bio: Lefty programmer n artist

body:
This is a fairly popular opinion. The American right wing loves to talk about "personal responsibility", and that's exactly what you are describing. 

These things aren't exactly conscious choices. I'm going to give one explanation for how these things happen, but this is just one part of the picture.   
People don't just wake up one day and decide "Today I will stop being a good student, will drop out of highschool, and will join a gang". It's a continual process of not-great decisions. For example, as a high schooler, I got caught smoking weed in the park. This was a bad decision. But the school admin who caught me didn't actually punish me, they just took my joint and told my parents. If I were a poor Black kid living in a poor neighborhood, there's a lot higher chance that I would have been given some disciplinary action, maybe even arrested. Most of my high school, friends, who were also white, got caught doing stupid shit at some point. But we were never seen as thugs, just kids smoking in a park. If every time I had done something dangerous or stupid, I had been punished more severely, and seen as more of a risk, I might have gone down a bad path, like the people you describe.

Also, the US has much *less* public assistance than most European nations.

body:
I'd almost agree with you, were it not for one detail: it's exceedingly hard to be a decent person when everyone around you is a pathetic little shit. Of course, this is an issue independent of race. After all, it doesn't matter if you're black or white, anyone can be born in the ghetto. If you end up with that hand, good luck getting out of it and leading a decent life.

In other words, I'd say, black people in America aren't inherently oppressed because they're black -- rather, it's more of a class issue than anything.

In other words, I'd say, black people in America aren't inherently oppressed because they're black -- rather, it's more of a class issue than anything.

body:
I agree with a lot of what you're saying, but honestly I'm not entirely sure anymore that this isn't the best they can do.

Look around the world - if this phenomenon was something related to the particular ghetto culture in the United States then the Blacks here would be underachieving relative to Blacks elsewhere. You'd have periods in history, as the Chinese do and the Arab/Muslim nations do, where they formed the preeminent civilizations in the world. But that isn't the case. If anything, they're MORE successful in the USA than anywhere else and they've never been more successful at any time in history than they are right now.

I say that knowing that there is a bell curve and this doesn't apply to everyone, but maybe Blacks just aren't collectively capable of succeeding in a world that runs at this speed. It might be that we're asking them to do things that they're just not as a rule capable of doing, and it angers and embarrasses them, and frustrates everyone else.

There... now THAT is how you write an unpopular opinion.

People like LBJ and Joe Biden were clear advocates of this. And they could get their votes too, because they robbed Peter to pay Paul thus tricking black people into thinking they're on their side now. They soon discovered that they could use this trick on other groups too, thus why they pretend to be so fanatical about minorities. The parties didn't actually switch sides, the Democrats become a more subtle about their true goals.

Maybe the reason a lot of black people are lazy and do bad things is because the media and the schools and colleges literally tell them 24/7 that they should be doing it because all white people are bad and they deserve it. And then racists get to quote racial crime statistics that are a result of this attitude. Really gets you thinking, doesn't it?

After all, it doesn't matter if you're black or white, anyone can be born in the ghetto. If you end up with that hand, good luck getting out of it and leading a decent life.

In other words, I'd say, black people in America aren't inherently oppressed because they're black -- rather, it's more of a class issue than anything.

body: I've noticed this phenomenon. I've met a few recently immigrated (at the time) African blacks. They had nothing in common with American black culture, freely admitted it, and were quite shamelessly vocal about their distaste for it and how lazy and juvenile it was. Meanwhile, the African blacks espoused hard work and were generally serious-seeming people. I was living in St. Louis at the time and the difference was beyond stark. There was absolutely nothing in common except their skin color.

parent.body: I'd say it's moreso culture than class. Asian and African immigrants tend to come over here poor as hell but they quite significantly outperform black people who were born here. It's really because American black culture holds people down and isn't conducive to producing productive members of society, and thus no upward mobility. Not American black culture as a whole actually, moreso inner city urban black culture.

author.bio: Nothing to see here

body: The issue is many of these people are manipulated into believing they are opressed. They live in poverty, which in itself forces them to pay more of their earned money (if at all any) then someone in the middle class. They are often marketed to heavily by many companies. Compare flyers from a ghetto area to a nicer neighbourhood. You will see people in ghettos are heavily marketed to unhealthy and cheap things that do not last a week. They waste what little money they have buying trash. The unhealthy stuff they will buy makes them feel like shit, causes them to be sick and will demotivate them over time. They end up stuck in the cycle of poverty and they never realise why they are stuck. They end up feeling worthless and forgotten, which often times makes them think crime is the only way. It is not and thats why there needs to be so many police in a ghetto neighbourhood. Black people are not opressesed, its just that so many are not realising that they need to get out of poverty instead of wasting their lives complaning, doing nothing and only waiting for their food stamps and welfare money. They have only been taken advatage by money hungry companies, who are often the same companies supporting that black people are opressed. This is so that these people keep paying for this crap. I know all this because I have watched this happen in my own neighbourhood. Fuck the idea that black people are opressesed. They have more opprutunities and options then ever in history, and the majority do not use them.

body:
Food stamps - EBT
Equal opportunity act
Black only colleges
Affirmative action

- I’m sure their are others that give/gave them a foot up. But that’s the problem. I can say maybe at one time they genuinely needed it, but it has long since stopped being helpful and started becoming a detriment to their lives and to society.
It’s like the old saying about teaching a man to fish.
Now we have blacks mostly overweight because they just buy junk food. They are more likely to be overweight, gay, and have abortions.
We also gain people in careers in important to society like nurses and dentists that are now under qualified because they got into college simply because of their race, and graduated because teachers were too afraid to fail them and be branded racists.

The black community used to stand for something. And it was healthier when it was genuinely fighting for something. But now they are a sick community that was given more resources than they know how to utilize and have become bloated from it.

The black community used to stand for something. And it was healthier when it was genuinely fighting for something. But now they are a sick community that was given more resources than they know how to utilize and have become bloated from it.

parent.body: The welfare state really is the fundamental root of so much of these issues. The biggest problem though is that the welfare state would be very difficult to dismantle. Running a very hardcore anti-welfare state campaign would probably make just about any campaign dead in the water. It's kind of discouraging to an extent just how obvious it is that the welfare state is a problem yet just how untouchable much of it is.

Why can't people just acknowledge that there is an institutionalized problem of racism in america without turning it into the mess it is now and also why can't they avoid to blatantly deny anything just because doesn't fit their narrative. STOP!

parent.body:
This is a fairly popular opinion. The American right wing loves to talk about "personal responsibility", and that's exactly what you are describing. 

These things aren't exactly conscious choices. I'm going to give one explanation for how these things happen, but this is just one part of the picture.   
People don't just wake up one day and decide "Today I will stop being a good student, will drop out of highschool, and will join a gang". It's a continual process of not-great decisions. For example, as a high schooler, I got caught smoking weed in the park. This was a bad decision. But the school admin who caught me didn't actually punish me, they just took my joint and told my parents. If I were a poor Black kid living in a poor neighborhood, there's a lot higher chance that I would have been given some disciplinary action, maybe even arrested. Most of my high school, friends, who were also white, got caught doing stupid shit at some point. But we were never seen as thugs, just kids smoking in a park. If every time I had done something dangerous or stupid, I had been punished more severely, and seen as more of a risk, I might have gone down a bad path, like the people you describe.

Also, the US has much *less* public assistance than most European nations.

body:
This one is tricky because it's both true and not true. I think a common error we make is assuming that somebody who belongs to a specific group can speak for that group. We all have unique experiences. I do feel there are some people that are oppressed because of their skin color. I feel that number is WAY fewer than what is being pushed by the media. However, I don't want to discount those who actually are. 

I think a lot of black Americans are prisoners of their own minds. If you're constantly told from a young age that you're oppressed you're very likely to adopt that idea. Any time you're mistreated you see it through the lenses of what you were taught and it validates the narrative. That's the primary reason I hate oppression narratives.

body:
Recently I read a book entitled Why Does He Do That by Lundy Bancroft. Fantastic book about domestic abusers and how they think. 

I know it was meant for couples, but after reading it, I noticed similar patterns in many “leaders” (political as well as social, educational), when it comes to people of color, but especially black people. 

The resulting reactions to abuse, while not helpful, make much more sense. 

If any of you read it and then take a look at leaders’ actions and words, let me know what you notice. 

I mean, having paternalistic leaders is always wretched, but there is more to it.  

I have also read The Underground History of American Education by John Taylor Gatto, which also helps the larger picture. 

Once all this is paired up with the upward mobility of intact black families, as a whole (not generalizing, but statistically) before certain welfare programs were aimed directly at certain groups (and they were, especially once one reads or watches Thomas Sowell and Walter E Williams discuss it), and the overarching picture of what is happening comes into view. 

None of this is to say they people don’t have agency, they do! And they must be required to exercise it. 

I’m just realizing what people need to know they’re fighting against. Acknowledging and naming main problems and challenges is the first step in overcoming them, right?

body:
I love this quote:

The Emperor summons before him Bodhidharma and asks: “Master, I have been tolerant of innumerable gays, lesbians, bisexuals, asexuals, blacks, Hispanics, Asians, transgender people, and Jews. How many Virtue Points have I earned for my meritorious deeds?”

Bodhidharma answers: “None at all”.

The Emperor, somewhat put out, demands to know why.

Bodhidharma asks: “Well, what do you think of gay people?”

The Emperor answers: “What do you think I am, some kind of homophobic bigot? Of course I have nothing against gay people!”

And Bodhidharma answers: “Thus do you gain no merit by tolerating them!”

body:
Your link makes a valid point about who benefits most directly from the government, but I think it misses some other important points:

1. Some of the benefits that are provided to poor people: education, food stamps, healthcare, housing, etc. Are arguably a benefit for all people in society. If we had more uneducated, homeless, sick and starving people, we would have more crime, higher costs for police and prisons, more unpaid ER visits, etc.

2. Immigrant farm workers that work under for cheap drive down the cost of food -- a benefit that the middle class directly benefits from without realizing it. The same thing happens when Walmart pays a puny salary and the workers collect government benefits to offset their cost of living. Because Walmart can pay their employees less, they can also offer their products for less, so the people that shop there benefit indirectly.

As a side note: I also don't think it is fair to generalize this argument into a racial one. While the problem is visible along racial lines, it is certainly more complicated than that. There are poor and uneducated white people and communities that suffer from these same problems.

One of the problems with the current media narrative is that they are drawing sweeping conclusions about people of a certain skin color based on statistics of national averages. To compare someone who is black or white in South Carolina to someone from Los Angeles is totally ridiculous. So why would we group those things together and draw statistics from it? Some black people are born in the United States, some immigrated here from other countries. Some white people living here are Russians and don't speak English. Even within native English speaking groups there is a vast variety of religious beliefs, political views and value systems. With so much economic and cultural diversity within the large "racial" groups how can we possibly make coherent points based on broad generalized groups? Instead of arguing against racism with racism, we should be arguing against the bullshit identity construction people call "race". There are many poor black and white people that have more in common with each other than they have in common with rich people of their own skin color.

body:
That's a wall of text, so I'll chiefly respond to two things.

1. This post wasn't intended to spark an argument about whether or not these programs are good or bad (although they are pretty devastating to the black community). Merely to say that the current framework *systematically* funnels metric shit tons of money from white people to black people. You can't make a reasonable argument that black people are systematically oppressed under such a framework.

2. You are trying to unnecessarily muddy the waters by talking about all the very small groups that sum up to form large demographics. Large, aggregate statistics certainly need to be taken in context. But when differences in them among races are so extremely pronounced, they cannot merely be explained away in this manner.

>Instead of arguing against racism with racism, we should be arguing against the bullshit identity construction people call "race". There are many poor black and white people that have more in common with each other than they have in common with rich people of their own skin color.

Race is not a bullshit identity construction. What kind of hippie trippy bullshit is this. Sure, we are all much more alike than different but let's not pretend there are no differences. Are we supposed to pretend that genetics isn't a thing?

It is not "racist" to form one's viewpoints around objective statistical reality. The sheer number of data points that informs these viewpoints is mind boggling. If it makes you feel better, most people seem to agree that at a fundamental level, it isn't a matter of race, but rather a matter of culture. The problem is race and culture are very highly correlated. Most people tend to agree inner city urban black culture is the biggest problem. It's just a lot more convenient to refer to race than the culture, and there isn't that much of a difference when 99.999% of the people who are raised in that culture are black.

If it makes you feel better, most people seem to agree that at a fundamental level, it isn't a matter of race, but rather a matter of culture. The problem is race and culture are very highly correlated. Most people tend to agree inner city urban black culture is the biggest problem. It's just a lot more convenient to refer to race than the culture, and there isn't that much of a difference when 99.999% of the people who are raised in that culture are black.

parent.body:
Your link makes a valid point about who benefits most directly from the government, but I think it misses some other important points:

1. Some of the benefits that are provided to poor people: education, food stamps, healthcare, housing, etc. Are arguably a benefit for all people in society. If we had more uneducated, homeless, sick and starving people, we would have more crime, higher costs for police and prisons, more unpaid ER visits, etc.

2. Immigrant farm workers that work under for cheap drive down the cost of food -- a benefit that the middle class directly benefits from without realizing it. The same thing happens when Walmart pays a puny salary and the workers collect government benefits to offset their cost of living. Because Walmart can pay their employees less, they can also offer their products for less, so the people that shop there benefit indirectly.

As a side note: I also don't think it is fair to generalize this argument into a racial one. While the problem is visible along racial lines, it is certainly more complicated than that. There are poor and uneducated white people and communities that suffer from these same problems.

One of the problems with the current media narrative is that they are drawing sweeping conclusions about people of a certain skin color based on statistics of national averages. To compare someone who is black or white in South Carolina to someone from Los Angeles is totally ridiculous. So why would we group those things together and draw statistics from it? Some black people are born in the United States, some immigrated here from other countries. Some white people living here are Russians and don't speak English. Even within native English speaking groups there is a vast variety of religious beliefs, political views and value systems. With so much economic and cultural diversity within the large "racial" groups how can we possibly make coherent points based on broad generalized groups? Instead of arguing against racism with racism, we should be arguing against the bullshit identity construction people call "race". There are many poor black and white people that have more in common with each other than they have in common with rich people of their own skin color.

At least trailer trash is its own culture and they're not just copying another crime culture.

body:
I think a lot of these things can be said about all races. In my experience, most people who feel the world is unfair to them and they deserve more and blah blah, fit most of what you listed above. Instead of recognizing that they are their own problem, they look for someone or something else to blame, and this is not exclusive to any one skin color. But in regards to black people specifically, they now have an entire movement behind them advocating that their own misfortunes are not their fault. Sure, not everyone buys into it, but many do and it’s concerning. 

I do absolutely agree that racism exists today, but I do feel it’s mostly at an individual level. I do not think it will ever disappear, much like I don’t believe rapists, murderers or thieves will ever disappear. It would be amazing if they did, but highly unlikely.

body: I see a lot of people coming down the same path as I am, I myself an African-American and I have had friends from different backgrounds of growing up. I have some who take advantage of all the tools granted to African Americans in America to make themselves better and go to help others. And I also see those who take advantage of it yet continue to stay lazy or not push for better change for themselves or others. I believe it all comes from the household. I grew up in a household of two parents who were always there for me and supported me throughout my life growing up. When your role model your parents are not giving you the example you need to be a better person you end up just repeating the same mistakes that they did. And I think that's where a lot of these problems root from the household of the African-American in these poorer neighborhoods and even in the middle class that continue to push stereotypes and negative views of life on their children . And they pass it on to their children and the cycle continues. There aren't a lot of African Americans who have made it up the ladder and have turned back to give another less fortunate a hand. And I believe that kind of roots from the idea that “I have to take care of myself before I even take care of others”. And from what I've seen they always think they have to take care of themselves and they never looked back to help the ones before. I saw a comment about how Asian Americans were in the same situation and I brought themselves up since then. One of the things I've seen growing up in an Asian community is that a lot of Asian Americans will choose to help in Asian American )thought sometimes brutally shunned can happen as well). I think if the United States citizens were more focused on helping each other as humans than as white, black, or Asian, Hispanic, etc. we'd see a huge increase in Unity across all races than the divide that we see today.

parent.body:
That's a wall of text, so I'll chiefly respond to two things.

1. This post wasn't intended to spark an argument about whether or not these programs are good or bad (although they are pretty devastating to the black community). Merely to say that the current framework *systematically* funnels metric shit tons of money from white people to black people. You can't make a reasonable argument that black people are systematically oppressed under such a framework.

2. You are trying to unnecessarily muddy the waters by talking about all the very small groups that sum up to form large demographics. Large, aggregate statistics certainly need to be taken in context. But when differences in them among races are so extremely pronounced, they cannot merely be explained away in this manner.

>Instead of arguing against racism with racism, we should be arguing against the bullshit identity construction people call "race". There are many poor black and white people that have more in common with each other than they have in common with rich people of their own skin color.

Race is not a bullshit identity construction. What kind of hippie trippy bullshit is this. Sure, we are all much more alike than different but let's not pretend there are no differences. Are we supposed to pretend that genetics isn't a thing?

It is not "racist" to form one's viewpoints around objective statistical reality. The sheer number of data points that informs these viewpoints is mind boggling. If it makes you feel better, most people seem to agree that at a fundamental level, it isn't a matter of race, but rather a matter of culture. The problem is race and culture are very highly correlated. Most people tend to agree inner city urban black culture is the biggest problem. It's just a lot more convenient to refer to race than the culture, and there isn't that much of a difference when 99.999% of the people who are raised in that culture are black.

One of the factors that come into play is this: Typically people who live in poorer areas have to try "harder" to succeed as compared to richer people - I'll leave this statement at that.

Typically poorer people are surrounded by negative influences that impact that person's lifestyle, which plays a role into what kind person they turn out to be.
